overview: The purpose of the advanced coursework is to develop professional and scientific skills necessary for general scientific inquiry. The knowledge gained will foster the student’s capacity to identify questions and generate ideas as well as providing a framework for students to use in order to approach and validate their ideas. Students will develop an understanding of experimental design, approach and evaluation, and skills in critical analysis of published experimental data. Students will also develop skills in written and oral forms of scientific communication.
ilo: Identify major advances in biomedical research
Write about research and data using a scientific style of writing
Communicate research and data in oral presentations
Read scientific articles with critical assessment of the content
Develop the ability to understand and critically evaluate data obtained by other researchers
Understand experimental design and statistics and be able to apply good experimental design
Establish a strong foundation in statistics as it applies biomedical scientific data
Synthesise a logical frame for their own hypotheses based on the literature and propose experiments to clarify scientific questions or resolve contradictory reports
Understanding biomedical research through specialised lectures
generic_skills: BH-BMED Bachelor of Biomedicine (Degree with Honours)
BH-SCI Bachelor of Science (Degree with Honours)

content: BH-BMED Bachelor of Biomedicine (Degree with Honours)
BH-SCI Bachelor of Science (Degree with Honours)

Corequisites.content: Students enrolled in the Bachelor of Biomedicine (Honours) or Bachelor of Science (Honours) must also be enrolled in the below subject:
BMSC40003 Medical Biology Research Project Part 1

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Journal Club presentation: 30mins presentation followed by 30mins student-led discussion with small group of peers
Written critique of Journal Article, submitted two weeks after presentation
Participation (have read the article and contribute to group discussion)
assessment.hurdle: 100% Attendance at Journal clubs within a group (~5 one hour sessions)

assessment.brief: Experimental Design and Statistics Online Quizzes (3 x quizzes)
Research Proposal, in the context of research experience to date, but not an assessment of research project itself (1,500 words plus figure)

assessment.hurdle: 80% attendance at postgraduate Lecture series (12 one hour lectures)

date_times.contact_hours: 24 hours: 5 x 60min journal clubs; 12 x 60min postgraduate seminar series attendance; 3 x 60min Experimental Design and Statistics tutorials; and 4 x 60min workshops.
